In the last week, some heavy hitters have warned about an AI bubble.

Jeff Bezos = Amazon 
David Solomon = Goldman Sachs
Roger McNamee = Elevation Partners

And below is Sam Altman, Founder of OpenAI (ChatGPT)

From the article ‚Ä¶
‚Äî‚Äî

Of course, when Altman makes these prophecies about AI, he‚Äôs also hyping it up. And perhaps part of why he can seem so nonplussed about impending catastrophes, financial or existential, is that he‚Äôs convinced that his company will be the one that comes out the other side stronger.

Right after warning of a bubble in August, Altman acknowledged that ‚Äúsomeone‚Äù will lose a ‚Äúphenomenal amount of money,‚Äù but that, of course, ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt know who.‚Äù
‚Äî‚Äî-

In other words, when the AI bubble pops, it will be ugly ‚Ä¶ for other people but not them. 

In fact, not only are they sure they will survive, but they want the bubble to pop because they think it will eliminate competition (so they can raise their monthly subscription fees) and even pick up cheap assets. 

They think the AI bubble popping means they win.

Good luck with this thinking.

Back in August I suggested that cutting mortgage rates was not going to lessen the housing affordability problem. 

Cutting mortgages was only going to push housing prices higher. Detailed here.

The repost below higher prices are now happening.
